key_title: Key to the species of Podolepis

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Asteraceae

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Asteraceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Jeanes, J.A. (1999). Asteraceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Lamina of involucral bracts transversely rugose at least towards the apex
Lamina of involucral bracts virtually smooth (sometimes wrinkled in dry specimens)
Ligules of ray corolla small and barely exceeding length of involucral bracts; far north-west and possibly extinct
Ligules of ray corolla well-developed and far exceeding length of involucral bracts; western Victoria
Apex of lamina of intermediate involucral bracts acute to aristate
Apex of lamina of intermediate involucral bracts retuse to obtuse
Basal leaves linear, mostly 3–6 mm wide, glabrous or nearly so; apex of involucral bracts usually long-acuminate to aristate; mostly from grasslands
Basal leaves usually lanceolate to oblanceolate, rarely linear, mostly 5–20 mm wide, variously hairy; apex of involucral bracts usually acute to acuminate; various habitats
Lamina of intermediate involucral bracts shorter than their claws; capitula usually 3–20 in terminal clusters
Lamina of intermediate involucral bracts similar in length or longer than their claws; capitula solitary or in loose or contracted cymes
Basal and cauline leaves linear; plants more or less glabrous or glabrescent except for prominent axillary hair tufts on basal leaves
Basal and cauline leaves not linear; plants variously hairy
Basal leaves to 20 mm wide; stems often several; capitula usually solitary, or rarely a few in loose cymes; slender plants mostly of lowland habitats but extending into the alps
Basal leaves 15–35 mm wide; stems usually solitary; capitula usually 5–11 in a dense contracted cyme; robust plants of montane to alpine habitats
Ligules of ray corolla yellow to orange, 9–13 mm long, teeth to 2 mm long; claw of involucral bracts c. 1 mm wide; capitula 15–25 mm diam.; mature cypselas <3 mm long
Ligules of ray corolla yellow, 14–20 mm long, teeth 2–4.5 mm long; claw of involucral bracts 1.5–2 mm wide; capitula 25–30 mm diam.; mature cypselas 3–4.5 mm long
Plants annual; capitula mostly 10–20 mm diam.; apex of involucral bracts acute
Plants perennial; capitula mostly 20–30 mm diam.; apex of involucral bracts more or less obtuse
